Namatjira's body is turned slightly towards the left, following his gaze. His left arm is bent at the elbow, the forearm leaning casually on his left thigh, his hand and fingers gently hanging down. Between this hand and his raised right hand, he gently holds a sketch of a landscape, resting on his lap, and angled away from his body. The paper faces towards us directly, showing a watery sketch of a landscape scene. A large tree on the right with grey green foliage, bright blue mountains in the background and pale peachy orange dirt in the foreground. 

Namatjira has dark taupe pants, his knees are parted, and he sits on a low reddish-brown rock.

**Audio description written by Marina Neilson and voiced by Lucie Shawcross, 2021**

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nCollection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of Jocelyne MacLeod 2008

Andree Johnston-Bell (1917-2007), pioneer publisher of articles on Australian antiques, was born in China of Belgian parents and educated in Belgium. After living for a time in Shanghai, she moved to Bombay early in World War 2. There, she became the editor of the Onlooker, a monthly glossy magazine, and moved in political and artistic circles, meeting Nehru, Gandhi and Tata. She married David Johnston-Bell, who was serving with Lord Mountbatten; they became friends with the Langhammers, and collected works by the artists in the Progressive School. After moving to Australia in 1950 the Johnston-Bells bought magazines including The Australian Collector, which under Andree's editorship soon became something of a collector's item in itself. One of her triumphs was the publication of previously-unseen engravings of botanical specimens collected by Banks and Solander. In retirement, she translated seventeenth-century French manuscripts. \n\nWalter Langhammer fled the Nazis in Austria for India, becoming first art director of the Times of India in about 1936. He was soon surrounded by an 'in crowd' of fellow European refugees - professionals, artists, doctors and industrialists - who became important patrons of contemporary artists in Bombay.

oil on masonite

Gift of Richard Elliott 2016. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Otte Bartzis

Peter Elliott AM (1926â€“2014) was an obstetrician, gynaecologist and oncologist as well as a significant art collector and patron. The son of a doctor, Elliott grew up in Bellingen, New South Wales, and was educated at Scot's College in Sydney. After war service with the Royal Australian Navy, he studied medicine at the University of Sydney, and decided to specialise in obstetrics and gynaecology in 1950 after witnessing Betty Sara become the first Australian woman to be successfully delivered of quadruplets (Elliot's father delivered them). Having undertaken further study in London, in due course he became head of gynaecological oncology at Sydneyâ€™s King George V Hospital, and president of both the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists and the Asian and Oceanic Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecology. For many years, Elliott worked as a volunteer in Asia and Oceania; and during his career he published over 150 research papers and delivered more than 250 lectures by invitation. In his spare time, he pursued his passion for art collecting, enjoying close relationships with gallery owners and artists, including Fred Williams, William Robinson, Frank Hodgkinson and Russell Drysdale.\n\nElliott commissioned this portrait from artist Jon Molvig in 1964. It was gifted to the National Portrait Gallery by the sitter's son in 2016, along with five of Molvig's preparatory drawings for the work.

oil on canvas

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the CSIRO Agriculture and Food Division 2017

Â© William Pidgeon/Copyright Agency, 2023

James Richard Vickery OBE (1902-1997), food scientist, saw the field of his lifeâ€™s research grow from non-existence to world recognition. Vickery graduated in biochemistry from the University of Melbourne in 1925, and fours year later earned a PhD from Cambridge, where he worked in the Low Temperature Research Laboratory. In 1929 he went as a biologist on a scientific survey party, sent from England at the request of the New Zealand government, to examine and report on aspects of the export lamb trade. Two years later he became officer in charge of the food preservation and transport section of CSIR at Cannon Hill, Brisbane. The primary objective of the section was to find a viable way to send chilled beef to Britain. In 1938 the section moved to Sydney, where further research into cold storage of diverse foods was carried out. In 1940 the section was raised to the status of a division with Vickery as its chief. In the next few years, owing to demands for supplies from the American forces in the Pacific, the section was expanded.; Vickery became the man in demand as wartime food supply problems intensified, and dehydrated meat for Allied forces became known as â€˜Vickery muttonâ€™. Vickery was careful to maintain close relations with the food industry, fostering good practice and innovation. He set up an education committee to implement the the first food technology courses in Australia at Hawkesbury Agricultural College and Sydney Technical College, and encouraged his staff to teach in them. Having travelled widely to observe food research establishments in many countries, Vickery became internationally recognised as one of the fathers of his profession; he was a member of the international committee that initiated the International Union of Food Science and Technology (IUFoST) and an honorary fellow of the UK Institute of Food Science and Technology. The Institute of Food Technologists conferred on him its International Award for 1960 for _â€˜outstanding efforts to promote international exchange of ideas in the field of food technologyâ€™_. By the time he retired in 1967, the division was housed in new laboratories at North Ryde and Cannon Hill. In retirement Vickery returned to the laboratory, publishing original research on cyclopropenoid fatty acids which cause pink/white disorder in eggs. In 1990 he published his comprehensive book _Food Science and Technology in Australia. Warmly remembered for his integrity, commitment and enlightened administration, he is commemorated in the JR Vickery Address, delivered at the annual convention of the Australian Institute of Food Science and Technology._ __

type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2017. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Ingvar Kenne

Akira Isogawa (b. 1964), fashion designer, was born in Kyoto, Japan, and first came to Australia at the age of 21. After immigrating, he worked as a waiter while studying fashion design at East Sydney TAFE and Sydneyâ€™s National Art School. In 1993 he opened the Akira Isogawa boutique in Woollahra, and swiftly established a reputation for his bold and intelligent clothes. At Sydneyâ€™s Australian Fashion Week in 1996, he sent all his models out wearing red socks from Gowings because he couldnâ€™t afford shoes for them; but he has shown at every Fashion Week since, and since 1998 he has shown twice annually in Paris. He has exhibited at the Museum of Contemporary Art, and Sydneyâ€™s Object Galleryâ€™s exhibition of his construction techniques is said to have been its most successful ever show. The National Gallery of Victoriaâ€™s _Akira Isogawa: Printemps EtÃ©_ in 2004-2005 was the first solo exhibition of an Australian designerâ€™s work to be shown at one of its major art institutions and later toured to Singapore, Manila and Bangkok. In 2005 Isogawa was depicted on the â€˜Australian Legendsâ€™ series of postage stamps and in 2007 he was named the countryâ€™s first Fashion Laureate. He has designed costumes for four Sydney Dance Company productions and for the Australian Balletâ€™s production of Graeme Murphyâ€™s _Romeo and Juliet_ in 2010. Sydneyâ€™s Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences showed the retrospective _Akira Isogawa_ at 2018-2019. Since the Woollahra boutique closed in 2017, Australiaâ€™s only two Akira boutiques are in the Strand Arcade, Sydney, and Fortitude Valley, Brisbane.

audio.title: Akira Isogawa
audio.transcript: When I look back, being a teenager growing up in a traditional city in Japan called Kyoto, I felt I was a bit of a fashion victim, really. Well now actually I create fashion. But back then, actually, I was consuming fashion and that's how much I loved [it].  \nJapanese culture is so different from Western ones. My grandparents had a house next door. They were all wearing actually traditional clothes â€“ kimono. What I noticed about kimono is actually they're made out rectangular shaped cloth. And they have no shapes. Whereas actually, Western clothes has a particular shape that enhance, particularly actually for female, the femininity of female body, but whereas actually kimono is totally unisex. I mean, I've never actually designed kimono myself. But being a kimono designer, I imagine actually, they work on texture, colour, print, and so on, because it's a highly textile driven fashion, and then to me, that's what Japanese fashion is all about. You know, when I design my own collection, I never really force myself to express my Japanese entity, but I feel that it just comes up naturally. And I think what's interesting is that not just, you know, designing something so traditionally Japanese, but then I kind of actually manage to fuse with Australian ease I guess actually. Australia has got this particular attitude â€“ friendly to start with â€“ but it's quite actually casual about things, you know. I feel actually my design is a result of actually, you know, some Japanese heritage with Australian attitude, which is actually friendly and easy.
audio.acknowledgements: This recording was made during interviews for the National Portrait Gallery's [_Portrait Stories_][1] series.\n\n [1]: /stories

text.content:
type C photograph on paper

Gift of the artist 2006

Â© Ingvar Kenne

Lee Lin Chin, stylesetter and former broadcaster, was born in Indonesia and raised in Singapore, where in 1968 she began working in television and radio. After arriving in Australia in 1980 she worked as a translator of Chinese language films and with ABC radio in Darwin and Newcastle before joining SBS as a newsreader in 1988, gaining devoted viewers through her stern delivery and superbly-cut tops and jackets. As host of the network's _Fashionista_ program she built a reputation as a style authority, in 2008 curating the National Archives of Australia exhibition of historical fashion photographs, _Strike a Pose â€¦ With Lee Lin Chin_. Known also as a comedian and a voice for social change, she has a huge social media following although she posts little, if anything, herself, retaining an intriguing air of mystery. Among the causes Chin supports is The Social Studio, an enterprise dedicated to creating employment and educational pathways for young people who have been refugees.\n\nPhotographer Ingvar Kenne spent a couple of hours with Lee Lin Chin in her friend's painting studio, and they went outside late in the afternoon so he could take 'one last shot' â€“ this one. He recalls 'we all ended up at the pub afterwards exchanging tales.' She is pictured in a dress by Japanese-born Australian designer Akira Isogawa.

labels.title: Aussie Icon: Portrait of Jenny Kee
labels.subtitle: Adrienne Doig

text.content:
synthetic polymer paint on wood

Purchased 2022

Â© Adrienne Doig/Copyright Agency, 2023

Artist Adrienne Doig employs self 

portraiture to explore her everyday life and examine political, social 

and environmental issues. She has created self portraits in various 

forms: from experimental video works to tea towels, needlepoint 

tapestries, soft sculptures and patchwork quilts. She first started 

experimenting with wooden nesting dolls when she was an art student in 

Sydney in the 1980s, but put her own spin on the format by making each 

doll in the set unique. Having made a number of self portraits this way,

Doig realised that multiple sets of nesting dolls would be the perfect 

way of capturing Australian fashion icon Jenny Kee AO (b. 1947) and her 

instantly recognisable, brightly-coloured designs. Doig initially 

thought sheâ€™d make one set of 10 Jenny Kee dolls. But seeing the 

multitude of garments Kee produced during their first meeting, Doig was 

â€˜dazzledâ€™ and ended up creating three different sets. â€˜I was able to 

really get obsessive about the details,â€™ Doig says. The set chosen for 

acquisition by the National Portrait Gallery shows some of Keeâ€™s most 

iconic knitwear designs, including the â€˜Blinkyâ€™ jumper made famous by 

Princess Diana during her 1982 royal visit.
oil on hessian\n\nPurchased 2023

Sydney-born Alison Rehfisch grew up in a family who encouraged her interest in art. She studied at Julian Ashtonâ€™s art school but left at the age of 19 to marry. After her daughter started school, Rehfisch returned to painting, studying at Antonio Dattilo-Rubboâ€™s atelier, where she met artist George Duncan. She held her first exhibition in 1929 and began exhibiting with the Society of Artists in 1931. By this time, she and her husband had separated. Heading to London in 1933, she studied at the Grosvenor School of Modern Art. Rehfisch once said she approached painting not as â€˜a superficial rendering of the thing we see in front of us, [but] trying to get the spirit behind all thatâ€™. Accordingly, this self portrait captures someone known for her sartorial flair as well as a sense of the independent, modern identity she forged as an artist in London.\n\nIn 1938, Rehfisch returned to Sydney, where she and Duncan married in 1942. From 1939 until 1969, she exhibited regularly in solo and group shows. She was particularly known for her still lifes and flowerpieces, often painted on hessian and always in a post-impressionist style that employed rhythmic, structured composition, simple forms and a bold yet harmonious use of colour.

audio.title: Alison Rehfisch
audio.transcript:
When my daughter reached school age, a terrific longing to paint came over me, I just had to do something like that. I joined Dattilo Rubboâ€™s classes. It was then that I really did start to work. He was a wonderful teacher. He realised I was an unconventional, peculiar sort of person really, and he rather encouraged it, not always approving but always sympathetic and helpful. It was there that I met my present husband, who has always been a help to me, with his encouragement and criticism and so on, George Duncan.

I worked seriously for years and years and from that day to now Iâ€™ve never ceased to paint.

Within the last few years, Iâ€™ve been extraordinarily interested in an ecological approach, which is the balance of life and place. I wanted to balance my subjects with something behind it, something deeper behind it. I think my early childhood feelings about trying to get behind things had something to do with it. Itâ€™s always been with me, always been interested in the other side of things. But somehow or other itâ€™s terribly difficult to get right behind things, as I think every artist should do. After all, itsâ€™ not just a superficial rendering of the things we see in front of us, itâ€™s trying to get the spirit behind all that and join it up with something, another life that isnâ€™t quite only of this world, and I expect I shall go along those lines for quite a while yet.

Usually, when Iâ€™m painting anything at all, things come to me. Iâ€™m slightly psychic, and things come to me in that peculiar period just between waking and sleeping. I see the whole composition, the colour scheme, the feeling of the thing, but I have to work out the detail, of course, physically, myself, afterwards; but the whole general feeling of the thing usually comes to me, and I never start an important work unless that happens because I find itâ€™s never any use at all.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Alison Rehfisch is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

text.content:
oil on canvas

Art Gallery of New South Wales, commissioned by the trustees 1919, received 1921

Â© AGNSW

In 1909, the artist DH Souter, writing about Tasmanian artist Florence Rodway in Art and Architecture, proclaimed gender played no role in the making of a great artist. This came a year after Victoria granted women â€“ but not Aboriginal women â€“ the right to vote in 1908, and the same year the Society of Women Painters was established, with the 27-year-old Rodway a founding member.

Rodwayâ€™s talents were recognised early by her parents, who sent her to study art at Hobart Technical School. In 1902, she was awarded a Royal Academy scholarship and studied for four years in London under visiting masters, including John Singer Sargent, before settling in Sydney and furthering her training with Julian Ashton. Her portraits were highly sought after; she completed commissions for soprano Dame Nellie Melba and poet Henry Lawson.

Although celebrated for her work in pastels, in 1919 Rodway was commissioned by the Art Gallery of New South Wales to paint in oil the ailing JF Archibald, a trustee of the Gallery since 1915. Despite the death of her subject that year, Rodway completed the work using direct sketches made during sittings. This was one of three portraits Rodway submitted for the inaugural award, alongside portrayals of Julian Ashton and chief justice Sir William Portus Cullen.
oil on canvas\n\nArt Gallery of New South Wales, gift of the artist 1922

The 1921 Archibald Prize went to Melbourne artist WB McInnes with his portrait of renowned Bendigo-born architect Harold Desbrowe Annear (1865â€“1933), instigating a rivalry between Victoria and New South Wales that lasted for decades.

Seven-time winner of the Archibald, McInnes dominated the competition for the first decade with his dark academic realism, his subjects often set against a gravy-brown background. After training at Melbourneâ€™s National Gallery School under Frederick McCubbin and Bernard Hall, he spent two years in Europe absorbing the work of Rembrandt, VelÃ¡zquez and Hals. After returning to Australia, he took up the post of drawing instructor at the Gallery School, becoming its head in 1934, and was acting director of the National Gallery of Victoria from 1935 to 1936.

With his wife, fellow artist Violet McInnes, he settled in the Melbourne suburb of Alphington, where Annear had lived. McInnesâ€™ arts and craftsâ€“styled villa, â€˜The Poplarsâ€™, was designed by Annear, who called for a shared vision in Australian domestic architecture, emphasising the forms of medieval art and imagery of nature, and forging the disciplines of art, architecture and craft.

Highly praised by critics at the time, the portrait shows the 56-year-old Annear settled beside a table littered with architectural drawings and items from his renowned collection of objets dâ€™art.
oil on linen\n\nIpswich Art Gallery Collection. Acquired with funds donated by the Ipswich Art Gallery Foundation, 2000

Thirty-seven years after Davida Allen became the fourth woman to win the Archibald Prize, her intimate and direct portrayals about her life as a wife, mother and woman still astound with their raw, emotional exuberance. Bold colour and thick, impasto surfaces, often painted using her hands, reflect Allenâ€™s affinity with German expressionist artists such as Emil Nolde.

For the 1986 Archibald, Allen had intended to submit a portrait of New Zealand actor Sam Neill, who had been the subject of a suite of satirical and provocative works in which she had explored sexual infatuation. Instead, she submitted this portrait of her father-in-law, retired 73-year-old physician John Shera.

Reflecting in 2021, Allen wrote:

â€˜One day I arrived unannounced while he was pottering about in the garden half naked! Instead of him quickly disappearing, he kept watering; unperturbed! On this day I was struck by an intimacy that was the linchpin to my returning with pencils and drawing pad to examine more closely the subject for a painting. I noticed his back was covered with seborrheic keratosis, which in turn I painted as thick brown blobs of paint. The final touch was bashing the green paint background of the painting with a branch off his celtis tree! It was a painting driven by emotion ...â€™
synthetic polymer paint on canvas\n\nCourtesy of the CBUS Collection of Australian Art

Predominantly a figurative and abstract painter, Vicki Varvaressos was hard-up when she decided to enter one of her first portraits into the Archibald Prize, hopeful she might win the $3500 prize money. The subject is Frank Watters (1934â€“2020), a passionate and influential art dealer and co-director of Watters Gallery, which was a stalwart of the Sydney art scene from 1964. Holding her first solo show at the gallery in 1975, Varvaressos remained part of its stable of artists until it closed in 2018.

When Watters died, he was widely remembered for his loyalty to artists, his ethics and his advocacy for experimental art practice. Varvaressos wrote:

â€˜I painted Frank in his apartment. He had just had his chair upholstered and I included a few of his many colourful objects. His walls (until recently) were always painted pink. When I was reminded of this painting decades later, I was surprised at the bright colours as I often am when seeing my early work. I was also struck by the slightly melancholic air about Frank. Although I had not been aware of it at the time, I later came to think that it captured something about him.â€™

That year was the second time no award was given (the first in 1964), with the trustees deciding to withhold the prize.
synthetic polymer paint, red ochre and plastic on canvas\n\nDowling Family Collection

At the age of 38, renowned Badimaya/Yamatji artist Julie Dowling became the first Aboriginal woman known to have had a work selected for the Archibald competition, with this portrait of her twin sister â€“ scholar, radio producer/announcer and activist Carol Dowling. Art-school trained, Julie has drawn upon diverse artistic sources, including European portraiture, and Christian and Aboriginal iconography and symbolism, developing a highly individual, hybrid style that explores â€˜what it means to be a Badimaya woman today and in the pastâ€™.

With her depiction of Carol tenderly embracing the familyâ€™s ailing dog Daisy, Julie explained: 

â€˜I see myself reflected through her face. I wanted to somehow show my twin that I understand her pain and that weâ€™ll share the sadness together. Itâ€™s also a painting of celebration. Weâ€™ve all survived such a long time together already and weâ€™ll survive this too.â€™

Carol wrote: 

â€˜â€¦ with every painting, Julie gives ownership to our communities with every story told within them. Julie has focused on healing and acknowledgement of how truly resilient and strong our people are despite all that has happened to us.â€™

oil on canvas

National Library of Australia, Canberra, nla.obj-136228916

Â© Robert Hannaford

A veteran of the Archibald Prize, Robert Hannaford has been represented 26 times over the past 30 years, once stating, â€˜I keep entering, as Iâ€™ve always done, to show my work to the widest possible audienceâ€™. Winner of the Peopleâ€™s Choice on three occasions, his subjects include former prime ministers Paul Keating (1998) and Malcolm Fraser (2010), as well as eight self-portraits. His courageous 2007 self-portrait was painted while recovering from life-threatening tongue cancer.

Largely self-taught, Hannaford took up painting full-time in 1970, encouraged by artists Hans Heysen and Ivor Hele, the latter a five-time Archibald winner. Rejecting contemporary trends in abstraction, Hannaford embraced realism, stating, â€˜I do try to capture the real, the accurate, colours, tones, shapes and movements in my visual field. In fact, this is what excites me more than anythingâ€™.

Hannafordâ€™s 1995 Archibald portrait depicts Wangkajunga and Walmajarri painter, printmaker and preacher Jarinyanu David Downs, shortly before his death in 1995. Born in the Great Sandy Desert around 1925, Downs was considered one of the leading lights of the contemporary Aboriginal art movement. Downsâ€™ works express his strongly held Christian beliefs coupled with representations of Walmajarri story cycles and specific cultural sites.
oil on canvas\n\nMoreton Bay Regional Council Art Collection, donated by Albert Scheinberg?

Following a brief period studying art at Swinburne Technical College, Melbourne-born Ray Crooke enlisted in the army in 1940, which took him to Cape York and Waiben (Thursday Island) and instilled in him a fascination for the peoples and landscape of Far North Queensland. After the war he completed his studies, but soon returned to Waiben where he began painting scenes of island life, for which he is best known.

In 1969, Crooke â€“ together with pilot and explorer Percy Trezise and Kunhanaamendaa artist Goobalathaldin (Dick Roughsey) â€“ began a search for the historical goldrush site Hells Gate, in the Kennedy Creek region of Cape York Peninsula. That same year Crooke won the Archibald Prize with a portrait of his close friend, novelist George Johnston. 

Born on Langunarnji Island in the Gulf of Carpentaria around 1920, Goobalathaldin was encouraged throughout his career by Trezise â€“ with whom he collaborated â€“ and Crooke, successfully exhibiting bark paintings and oils, and creating illustrated childrenâ€™s books. In 1971 his book Moon and rainbow was the first published autobiography by a First Nations person and, in 1973, he became the first chair of the Aboriginal Arts Board. In his 1982 Archibald work, Crooke depicts the artist in his studio, surrounded by his works celebrating Kunhanaamendaa culture and traditions. Goobalathaldin died in 1985.

labels.title: Ritratto del Maestro (Portrait of Cav A Dattilo-Rubbo)
labels.subtitle: Frances Ellis

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nCollection of the Sarjeant Gallery Te Whare o Rehua Whanganui New Zealand. Gift of the artist, 1959

Frances Dolina Ellis was born in Papaioea (Palmerston North) in 1900 and in her youth showed both musical and artistic talent. She travelled to London in 1923, studying at the Central School of Arts and Crafts under Bernard Meninsky, who instilled in her a lifelong interest in colour. After a brief sojourn in Australia, Ellis taught drawing at the technical and high schools in Papaioea, where she studied under Harry Linley Richardson.

In 1934, Ellis returned to Australia, enrolling in the classes of Italian Ã©migrÃ© artist Antonio Dattilo-Rubbo (1870â€“1955), an early supporter of modernism in Sydney. Ellis held a two-woman show in 1938 with Dora Toovey, and by 1941 was appointed principal of Dattilo-Rubboâ€™s art school, where she remained until 1949.

Influenced by the post-impressionist teachings of Dattilo-Rubbo, Ellis greatly admired Paul CÃ©zanne and her work reflects a cubist approach in its use of faceting and colour divisions. This portrait of the â€˜maestroâ€™ received his highest praise; Dattilo-Rubbo wrote: 

â€˜â€¦ you have achieved the best by a good composition, supported by strong drawing, virile colour and excellent touch. It is a well-balanced work, and I heartily congratulate you with my good wishes to see the painting hanged in [a] worthy art gallery â€“ if possible, in your native land.â€™
oil on canvas\n\nCollection of the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Gift of Mr AL and Miss Richardson, son and daughter of the artist, 1948

Harry Linley Richardson, Surrey-born son of artist George Richardson and Mary Linley, pursued art training in London through Goldsmithsâ€™ College then Westminster School of Art, before finishing studies at the AcadÃ©mie Julian in Paris in 1900. He worked as a painter, illustrator and teacher before emigrating to Aotearoa New Zealand in 1908, where he was appointed an art instructor at Wellington Technical College.

With a keen interest in MÄori culture, Richardson is noted for his detailed and precise portraits of distinguished MÄori. He is one of nine artists based in Aotearoa known to have exhibited in the Archibald, from Annie Elizabeth Kelly in 1922 to John Ward Knox in 2020.

This work, Richardsonâ€™s only entry in the Archibald Prize, portrays Dorothy Kate Richmond, a fellow member of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts, who was 63 at the time. Born in TÄmaki Makaurau (Auckland), as a child Richmond was taken on a Grand Tour of Europe, studying art and music. She was a scholarship holder at Londonâ€™s Slade School, later travelling for two years around Europe with childhood friend, artist Frances Hodgkins. A much-loved art educator, Richmond was admired for her poise, charm and intellect, qualities that Richardson eloquently captures in this faithful depiction.

oil on canvas

Collection: National Portrait Gallery Gift of the artist 2002

Â© Jean Goldberg/Copyright Agency, 2023

Carola â€˜Olaâ€™ Cohn (1892â€“1964) was born in Bendigo, Victoria and studied sculpture at Swinburne in Melbourne before taking up a scholarship at the Royal College in London under renowned British sculptor Henry Moore. Cohn was a pioneer in Australia, fashioning colossal modernist sculptures, hand-carved in stone. Described by writer and friend Barbara Blackman (the subject of the 1997 winning portrait by Nigel Thomson) as â€˜a big flour bag of a woman, healthy as bread, strong as a millstoneâ€™, Cohn had a studio-home that was a meeting place for Melbourneâ€™s artistic community. It was here that Jean Goldberg and Cohn met in 1956, becoming close friends.

Goldberg studied nursing at Royal Melbourne Hospital, graduating in 1948. In the 1950s, she became a passionate advocate for human rights and protested social injustice. Taking life classes with Cohn in the mid 1950s, Goldberg then studied at George Bellâ€™s studio from 1956 to 1959. She later learned needlepoint lacemaking while working as a librarian at the Embroiderersâ€™ Guild, Victoria. Goldberg went on to create idiosyncratic and witty lace pieces from everyday subjects, including newspaper advertisements for cars.

In her only Archibald Prize work, Goldberg fills the canvas with Cohnâ€™s forceful presence, the stocky figure and tousled grey hair built up with thick daubs of paint. Cohnâ€™s vocation is distinguished by one of her sculptures, shown in the background.
oil on composition board\n\nNational Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne Purchased, 1956

The subject of this portrait, British-born sculptor Paul Beadle (1917â€“92), settled in Australia in 1946, following his discharge from the Royal Navy at the end of World War II. Having studied sculpture at Londonâ€™s Central School of Arts and Crafts, in 1947 Beadle became an instructor at the East Sydney Technical College (ESTC) Strathfield campus. An influential educator, he also taught at Newcastle Art School and his public art can be seen across Newcastle. In 1961, Beadle settled in Aotearoa New Zealand, where he became known for his figurative, lost-wax cast sculptures.

Novocastrian Jon Molvig was a soldier in New Guinea and the Philippines during World War II and was a student under the Commonwealth Reconstruction Training Scheme at ESTC, where he met Beadle. After graduation, Molvig left Sydney in 1951 for Europe, where he studied the work of modern masters such as Pierre Bonnard and Edvard Munch. His highly individual works encompass the genres of portraiture, landscape and, in his final years, abstraction.

Molvig painted Beadle the year after the sculptor completed his most celebrated commission â€“ the 11-metre-high eagle and sphere surmounting the Australianâ€“American Memorial in Canberra. It was the first of 11 Archibald portraits by Molvig (he won in 1966 with his portrayal of artist Charles Blackman) and was painted the year Molvig left Sydney for Brisbane, where he remained until his death, aged just 46.

oil on canvas

Mr N and Mrs A Pezikian Collection, Sydney

Â© Wendy Sharpe

After a hiatus of ten years, Wendy Sharpe became the fifth woman to take home the Archibald with this unabashed self-portrait, in which she humorously assumes the guise of the Roman goddess Diana, her hunting bow replaced by paintbrushes. It was the first self-portrait by a female artist to win, and one of four self-portraits Sharpe exhibited in the Archibald from 1994 to 2020.

Sharpeâ€™s influences are broad, including expressionist painters Max Beckmann, Edvard Munch and Emil Nolde, and Australian artists Arthur Boyd and Kevin Connor. Her exuberant, richly coloured canvases are filled with the epicurean bodies of stage performers, with dramatic lighting creating evocative settings for her figures. In 1993, she wrote: 

â€˜a figurative artist acts as a kind of stage magician theatrically conjuring up people and places. Ideas, experiences are personified, or made visible; the incorporeal is metamorphosised into human, ghost or allegorical figures.â€™

A graduate of City Art Institute (now UNSW Art & Design), Sharpe has held over 70 solo exhibitions. In 1999, she was appointed an official war artist â€“ the first woman since World War II â€“ assigned with troops in East Timor.

labels.title: Kungkarangkalpa tjukurpa (Seven Sisters dreaming), a self-portrait
labels.subtitle: Tjungkara Ken

text.content: synthetic polymer paint on linen\n\nPrivate collection, Armidale

Following in the footsteps of Yulparija artist Weaver Jack, whose depiction of Country was a controversial portrait in the 2006 Archibald Prize, Tjungkara Kenâ€™s bravura self-portrait defies the Western art historical canon, with her painting of self as a living embodiment of Country. A century after the inaugural Archibald Prize, the notion that a personâ€™s identity may be revealed in portraiture through codified cultural designs has progressively become accepted practice.

An artist at Tjala Arts on Aá¹‰angu Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara (APY) Lands, Tjungkara Ken, with the Ken Sisters Collaborative, won the 2016 Wynne Prize for landscape painting, with their work depicting the Seven Sisters. As the sisters are being chased across Country by an evil man named Wati Nyiru, they work together to avoid falling for his tricks. Wati Nyiru can change shape into different rock formations and landmarks. These sites, which Ken paints, remain part of the landscape and are cared for by the artist and her family. In her Archibald self-portrait, Ken also paints the Seven Sisters, coalescing the genres of landscape and portraiture.

In 2015, Ken said, â€˜I hold my fatherâ€™s story, I hold my motherâ€™s story â€¦ [it] doesnâ€™t come out of paper or out of a book. Itâ€™s coming out of the ground hereâ€™.

labels.title: Mr and Mrs Horace Keats in the "Christopher Brennan Cycle"
labels.subtitle: Dora Toovey

text.content:
oil on canvas

Gift of Anne and Brennan Keats 2009

Â© Estate of Dora Toovey

Soprano Janet Keats (nee le Brun Brown, 1900â€“85) was recently widowed when Dora Toovey painted this portrait. Janetâ€™s husband, composer Horace Keats (1895â€“1945), had died earlier that year and poet Christopher Brennan (1870â€“1932) â€“ whose otherworldly presence drifts in the background â€“ 13 years prior. Janet â€“ whose stage name was Barbara Russell â€“ holds one hand across her heart while the other clutches sheet music, presumably arrangements written by her husband, who had set Brennanâ€™s poetry to music. Words from the poem â€˜I am shut out of mine own heartâ€™ can be discerned. It was the last song the couple performed. \n\nThe Keatses lived in Mosman on Sydneyâ€™s North Shore, where Toovey also resided. The artist had studied in Sydney with Antonio Dattilo-Rubbo, who is included in Archie 100 as a sitter. Inspired by Nora Heysenâ€™s 1938 win, Toovey determined to study portraiture, stating, â€˜When I saw that it was possible for a woman to win, I decided to try my hardest and went straight to Melbourne where I studied for my diploma in portraiture at the Melbourne National Galleryâ€™. Her marriage to artist James R Jackson â€“ an Archibald artist in 1922 with two portraits â€“ was strained while Toovey was working on this portrait, which conveys an overwhelming feeling of grief and melancholy and foreshadows Toovey and Jacksonâ€™s divorce two years later.
oil on canvas\n\nCollection of the artist

John Olsen remains the oldest artist to win the Archibald Prize to date, with this complex and enigmatic work, painted in his 77th year. In it, he alludes to both the impact the Australian landscape has borne on his work, as well as the passage of time as he approached his eighties. The work references the ancient Roman god of beginnings, transitions and ending. Responding to his win, Olsen said: â€˜Janus had the ability to look backwards and forwards and when you get to my age you have a hell of a lot to think aboutâ€™. Contemplative and full of raw intensity, the tracery of lines that emblematically map out the artistâ€™s life journey â€“ traversing his six-decade-long career â€“ appear fragile, as if fading into oblivion.\n\nOlsenâ€™s association with the Archibald goes back to 1952, when he joined a group of art students at the Gallery protesting William Dargieâ€™s seventh Archibald win (for a portrait of BHP chairman Essington Lewis). Holding a placard that read â€˜Archibald decisions death to art!â€™, Olsen gave three cheers for Picasso, and left. The protest led to a term limit for Gallery trustees. Years later, Olsen himself became a Gallery trustee and, by default, an Archibald judge. In yet another Archibald controversy, Olsen had been the favourite to win the 1989 prize for his work DÃ³nde voy? Self-portraits in moments of doubt. Instead, the award went to Bryan Westwood for his portrait of art critic and artist Elwyn Lynn.

labels.title: Art, life and the other thing
labels.subtitle: Brett Whiteley

text.content: oil, photograph and mixed media on board\n\nPurchased by the New South Wales State Government 1994, transferred to the Gallery 1998

This was Brett Whiteleyâ€™s second self-portrait in the Archibald Prize to win. His first â€“ Self-portrait in the studio 1976 â€“ marked a formative moment in the history of the award, which challenged the definition of portraiture.

In Art, life and the other thing â€“ a brutally honest confession of his heroin addiction â€“ Whiteley not only defied traditional canons of likeness and realism, he also confronted the Archibaldâ€™s own fraught history. In the central panel, Whiteley holds a drawing of William Dobellâ€™s infamous 1943 Archibald-winning portrait of fellow artist Joshua Smith, his own torso elongated in deference to Dobell. To the left, a baboon howls as a ghostly hand offers a syringe. On the right is a photograph of Whiteley, seemingly high. Commenting on Whiteleyâ€™s work during this period, the artist Donald Friend wrote: â€˜His paintings are like wonderful glimpses of the world seen through holes in the death-wishâ€™. Sadly, Whiteley died in a hotel room from an overdose in 1992.

In 1978, Whiteley not only won the Archibald, but also the Wynne Prize for landscape painting and the Sulman Prize for genre painting â€“ the only artist to date to win the trifecta.
oil on linen\n\nCourtesy of the artist

Following his Archibald success, Quilty toured with Australian troops as the official war artist for the Australian War Memorial in October 2011. Stationed in Tarin Kot, Afghanistan, he witnessed the daily activities of the soldiers as they trained and prepared â€“ physically and emotionally â€“ for the perils ahead. One soldier, Captain S, recounted to Quilty his terrifying experience in the Helmand province. Forced to take cover for 18 hours behind a mud-brick wall, while under constant fire from insurgents, he continued to command aircraft gunfire and coordinate the medical evacuation of a seriously wounded young soldier.

Quiltyâ€™s portrait was made from a live sitting in his studio in the Southern Highlands, NSW. The artist explained: 

â€˜The pose for this painting was chosen by Captain S [â€¦] I wanted Captain S to be naked, showing not only his physical strength but also the frailty of human skin, suggesting the darkness of the emotional weight of the war.â€™

Visceral and highly charged, this portrait evokes the harrowing intensity of war and its consequences, including post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and other psychological and corporeal wounds suffered by those who face unimaginable horrors during military service.
oil on composition board\n\nHeide Museum of Modern Art, Melbourne On long-term loan from the Albert & Barbara Tucker Foundation

Albert Tucker was one of the Angry Penguins group of artists, whose fiercely modernist outlook sent shockwaves through the art establishment of 1940s Melbourne. Tuckerâ€™s often grim imagery depicts the devastation he experienced through the Great Depression and World War II. With no formal training, he studied reproductions of works by post-impressionist and expressionist artists in the cityâ€™s public library. During his army service, he created potent images of the physical and mental traumas he witnessed in patients at Victoriaâ€™s Heidelberg Military Hospital in 1942. Meeting esteemed psychiatrist Dr Reginald Ellery, Tucker began exploring the intersection between psychology and creativity.

As Tucker was an avid reader of the stream-of-consciousness poetry of TS Eliot, it was almost inevitable that he crossed paths with the poet Max Dunn (c1895â€“1963), an enigmatic figure in Australian literature. Dunn went by various names â€“ most of them invented â€“ and later became president of the Buddhist Society of Victoria. He self-published his Eliot-inspired poems in the 1940s to a largely bewildered public. Tuckerâ€™s portrait is imbued with a dark undercurrent: Dunnâ€™s gaunt features are exaggerated, while his body emerges from a shadowy background. Broad, agitated brushstrokes conjure the â€˜social-psychological landscapeâ€™ Tucker sought to embody in each of his portraits.

This was one of two portraits by Tucker in the 1945 Archibald; the other â€“ an intense self-portrait â€“ was the last of three self-portraits he exhibited in the competition.
oil on plywood panel on composition board\n\nNational Library of Australia, Canberra

Renowned writer and feminist Mary Gilmore (1865â€“1962) â€“ a contemporary of bush poet Henry Lawson â€“ was a passionate campaigner for a wide range of social reforms, including womenâ€™s suffrage and emancipation for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and Australiaâ€²s poor. A celebrated public figure and doyenne of Sydneyâ€™s literary world, she is featured on Australiaâ€™s $10 banknote. Portraits of Gilmore were included in the Archibald 11 times by eight artists.

Adelaide Perryâ€™s artistic career began in Melbourne at the National Gallery School. Awarded a travelling art scholarship in 1920, she attended Londonâ€™s Royal Academy under Walter Sickert, later working in Paris. In Sydney, she established herself as an artist and role model for generations of artists, both through the Adelaide Perry School of Art and her 30-year-tenure as art mistress at Presbyterian Ladiesâ€™ College, Croydon. In 2001, the Adelaide Perry Gallery was established at PLC Sydney (as the girls school is now known) and every year hosts the Adelaide Perry Prize for Drawing.

In the interwar period, Perry exhibited with Contemporary Group artists, including Margaret Preston and Grace Cossington Smith, whose work represents the first significant wave of modernist culture in Australia. She was also a member of the more established Society of Artists and later the Australian Academy of Art, thereby traversing Sydneyâ€™s contemporary and conservative artistic milieu. Perryâ€™s portraits are characterised by her commitment to realist techniques, with impeccable draughtsmanship, tonal modelling and an emphasis on form, using crisp outlines.

oil on canvas

Queensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art, purchased 1957

Â© Estate of William Dargie Photo: QAGOMA

This bravura portrait of Western Arrernte artist Albert Namatjira (1902â€“59) by William Dargie is probably the most recognisable and universally respected of all Archibald winners. By the 1950s, reproductions of Namatjiraâ€™s watercolours of his Country adorned the walls of Australian middle-class homes.

Born at Ntaria (Hermannsburg) on Western Arrernte Country â€“ and briefly tutored by artist Rex Battarbee â€“ Namatjira laid the foundations for the Hermannsburg painting movement. Dargie admired his defiance of bureaucracy and exploitation, and First Nations artists today â€“ including his great-grandson Vincent Namatjira â€“ are stirred by his legacy. In 1957, Namatjira was the first Aboriginal person granted Australian citizenship. Despite his artistic success, Namatjira died broken-spirited, aged 57 years, his anguish and resilience perceptible in this portrait.

Dargie trained under Archibald Colquhoun â€“ who had 36 portraits in the Archibald Prize between 1926 and 1960 â€“ and Napier Waller at Melbourne Technical College. However, he was most inspired by the work of John Longstaff. Dargie was rewarded by Archibald judges eight times between 1941 and 1956 â€“ a record unmatched in the prizeâ€™s history. His 1952 success led to protests by art students, who brought a dachshund to the Gallery wearing the placard: â€˜Winner Archibald Prize â€“ William Doggieâ€™. Dargieâ€™s staunchly realist portraits often lacked the freshness and vitality seen in this portrait, which was painted in Sydney during a visit by Namatjira to the city.
oil on linen\n\nTweed Regional Gallery Collection Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program by the J Sages Family Trust, 2008

Acclaimed for her abstract landscape works, Jenny Sages was a regular Archibald contributor for over 20 years, winning the 2012 Peopleâ€™s Choice award. Born in Shanghai to Russian Jewish parents, Sages studied commercial art in Sydney and New York before embarking on a career in fashion illustration. Becoming a full-time artist in her fifties, Sages met and painted Anmatyerre artist Emily Kngwarreye during one of Sagesâ€™ many expeditions to Central Australia; her landscape, The road to Utopia, won the 2005 Wynne Prize. Her Archibald sitters have included dancer Meryl Tankard, author Helen Garner and Dutch-born filmmaker Paul Cox, shown in this portrait, whose body of idiosyncratic films Sages greatly admired.

Lauded as the father of Australian independent cinema, Cox wrote and directed the critically acclaimed documentary Vincent in 1987. Here, Sages casts the director in his home, pipe in hand. Behind him, an image of Van Goghâ€™s Self-portrait with bandaged ear and pipe 1889 offers insight into Coxâ€™s state of mind. The 56-year-old filmmaker was about to leave for America, unable to source funding in Australia for his next project. Silhouetted against a bright sunlit window, the contours of Coxâ€™s face and troubled countenance are sensitively conveyed. Painted over a four-month period, Sages recalled, â€˜It was a terribly moving experience for meâ€™.

Paul Cox died in 2016, aged 76.
egg-oil emulsion on board\n\nUniversity Art Collection, Chau Chak Wing Museum, the University of Sydney, purchased with funds from the Robert Stein Memorial Portrait Fund, 1993

Alice Erh-Soon Tay (1934â€“2004) was born in Singapore, where she became a barrister. Emigrating to Australia in 1961, Tay was appointed the Challis Professor of Jurisprudence at the University of Sydney in 1975, and in 1986 was made a Member of the Order of Australia for her â€˜contribution to teaching and research in lawâ€™. Committed to the promotion of human rights, she was president of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. She encouraged the contribution of women from diverse backgrounds to public life.

A student at the Julian Ashton Art School in the 1970s, Jenny Giacco (nee Pollack) also trained under realist painter Brian Dunlop, whose work she greatly admired. Dunlop encouraged her to travel to Europe, where she studied masterpieces of the Italian Renaissance and learned the painstaking technique of egg-oil emulsion. She won the 1989 Portia Geach Memorial Award with a portrait of printmaker Alex Karpin, whom she had also painted for the Archibald (1989, 1990), exhibiting under the pseudonym Jenny Sands. Her husband, Francis Giacco, won the 1994 Archibald with his Homage to John Reichard.

Commissioned by the University of Sydney, Jenny Giaccoâ€²s portrait of Tay was completed over several months at the artistâ€²s studio, Tay always arriving meticulously attired and hair perfectly coifed. Giaccoâ€™s precisely rendered composition is a measured arrangement of objet dâ€™art and exquisite textiles, with a subtle dignity befitting her subject.
oil on composition board\n\nQueensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art, bequest of Dr Robert Graham Brown 1946

There are only ten known portraits of First Nations people in the first three decades of the Archibald Prize; William Bustardâ€™s portrait of Jetimarala man Timothy â€˜Tippoâ€™ Powder (1914â€“72) is one of them. 

Powder was born at Yatton Station, Queensland and forcibly relocated to Woorabinda Mission as a child. In the 1940s his skills as a buckjumper at country shows and boxer in Rockhampton boxing stadium were celebrated, and he was known for being an excellent accordion player. He was also a successful tracker, whose expertise in solving missing person cases led to two transfers to Victoria Police in the 1930s and late 1950s. A highly developed knowledge and skill refined by Aboriginal people, the ability to track or â€˜readâ€™ the landscape led to the establishment of Victoria Policeâ€™s own corps of Queensland Aboriginal trackers in the 1880s. 

Bustard was an exceptional draughtsman, who studied at Londonâ€™s Slade School. His urban and rural landscape painting brought him wide recognition and influence. In 1921 he emigrated to Australia and quickly established himself as a stained-glass designer, having restored European medieval church windows damaged during the war. 

This captivating portrait, with its radiant palette and free brushwork, presents 29-year-old Powder at the height of his fame in the boxing ring and as a Rockhampton Police tracker.

oil on board

Gift of Richard Brian Close, Githabul people, Woodenbong 2000. Donated through the Australian Government's Cultural Gifts Program.

Â© Estate of Clif Peir

Poet, environmentalist and activist Oodgeroo Noonuccal (Kath Walker, 1920â€“93) was born on Minjerribah (North Stradbroke Island). Throughout the 1950s and 1960s, Noonuccal campaigned for equal citizenship rights for First Nations people. She became the first published Aboriginal poet with her 1964 book We are going, dubbed a â€˜battle cryâ€™ against social injustice. In 1971, Noonuccal returned to Minjerribah where she started a learning centre named Moongalba.

Clif Peirâ€™s work is unfamiliar to most, despite the gallery of notable subjects he painted for the Archibald. While working as a Sydney County Council designer, Peir studied part-time at the Julian Ashton Art School with Archibald artists Joshua Smith and Eric Wilson, and exhibited extensively. His interest in drama led him to stage design, with his portraits possessing a theatrical quality. From 1950, Peir travelled extensively in Central Australia, the Northern Territory and Flinders Ranges in South Australia. He painted First Nations people and desert landscapes, and his work featured in the 1982 exhibition Art sale for land rights.

This portrait was painted at the artistâ€™s family home in Oatley, where Noonuccal stayed on her visits to Sydney. Peirâ€™s realism verges on surrealism; the poetâ€™s elongated figure against a vast, green-tinged vista is reminiscent of the dreamlike figure-landscapes of Russell Drysdale.

audio.title: Kath Walker part two
audio.transcript:
In 1965 I think it was, we were invited to go in and talk to the then prime minister, Sir Robert Menzies. There was a deputation from all over Australia of Aboriginal spokesmen and women and we did go in. Sir Robert Menzies had told the public and the politicians, the people of the House, that he would not have a referendum in his lifetime as prime minister. Heâ€™d been badly beaten on the referendum before where he had appealed to the people to outlaw Communism and when the people said â€˜No outlawing of the Communist Partyâ€™, Sir Robert Menzies refused then to have anything to do with referendums in his lifetime as prime minister.

We lobbied the House of Parliament and itâ€™s to their discredit, really, that when we asked them to bring out the laws concerning the Aboriginal people that there was no laws, no books on the Aboriginal people in their archives or libraries, and they had to quickly have them printed, so that the politicians could read what it was, for and against the Aborigines. There was one, however, on the national â€“ the Canberra law book saying that if Aboriginals go into Canberra, any Justice of the Peace could declare them illegal immigrants into Canberra and they could be chased out of Canberra. This still applied to us, incidentally, at this period of time. And we always made a joke of it when we went to Canberra, you know, â€˜If you get into trouble, you know the law on the book. If a JP says Get Out, make sure you get your blanket,â€™ because the law still said that before sending them out of Canberra, they must first issue them with one government blanket. So we were determined weâ€™d get our government blanket if ever they threw us out.  
We told everyone this and we made it a laughingstock â€“ Canberra a laughingstock â€“ to such an extent that the first thing Sir Robert Menzies did was delete that off the Canberra constitution. So itâ€™s no longer there.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

audio.title: Kath Walker part one
audio.transcript:
I would say that the majority of the Australian people voted Yes in favour of the Aboriginal people merely to clear their guilty conscience. Itâ€™s easy to put a mark on a ballot paper, and I must say this definitely, that there was a small minority group of sincere Australian people but I would say 75 [per cent] of those who voted Yes did it to clear their guilty conscience.

Incidentally, itâ€™s interesting to understand why those terrible discriminative laws were put into the books. In the first place, our civic fathers, or the white manâ€™s civic fathers of long ago, during the â€˜soothing of the dying pillowâ€™ era, the politicians, or the statesmen of that time, were writing over to Queen Victoria saying, â€˜The Aborigine is dying out.â€™ And true, he was â€“ they were poisoning him with strychnine in the waterholes and they were shooting him, and they were doing all sorts of things. And the Aborigine dropped from 300,000 strong to 80,000 in a very short period of time. So it was quite natural for them to say the Aborigine was a dying race.

Now it was during this period of time that the Constitution was being fixed, and as they thought we were a dying race, to save themselves a lot of bother they said, â€˜Well we will not count the Aborigines and we do not have to make laws for the Aborigines, because theyâ€™re going to die out anywayâ€™. And this is the reason today why Aboriginals have not had any education, any decent housing, any facilities that the white Australian enjoys today. Itâ€™s because of that stupid business of thinking the Aboriginals were going to die out.

Mind you, the Aboriginals are a determined lot, and theyâ€™re quite ungrateful. They didnâ€™t die, they lived on and are still living on; in spite of the many attempts to commit genocide and assassinate us all, we are still here. I think weâ€™ll last the white man out, truly.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Kath Walker is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

labels.title: 'A true Territorian': Portrait of Grandma Lum Loy
labels.subtitle: Geoff La Gerche

text.content:
oil on canvas

Museum and Art Gallery of the Northern Territory, gift of the artist, 1993

Â© Geoff La Gerche Photo: MAGNT, Mark Sherwood

Lim Lee See (c1884â€“1980), known as Granny Lum Loy â€“ the matriarch of Darwinâ€™s Chinese community â€“ was a pioneering market gardener. It is not known when she was born (probably between 1884 and 1891) but she emigrated to Australia from Guangdong, China as a child. In this portrait, her weathered skin and arresting presence embody her abiding resilience; she survived two world wars, the deaths of her husband and only daughter, and the destruction of her gardens by Cyclone Tracy in 1974.

Geoff La Gerche was dubbed an â€˜eyeball realistâ€™ for his super-scaled portraits, which were a commanding feature of the Archibald Prize in the late 1970s. Following formal studies in Melbourne, La Gerche departed for London in 1967. At the Royal College of Art, his teacher, American pop artist Jim Dine, had a profound effect on his work. Returning to Australia, La Gerche utilised air-brushed acrylics to achieve precise renderings of light and shade in his early hyper-real works. In 1979, La Gerche took up an artist residency in Darwin. There, he produced a series of vast landscapes painted with finely textured brushwork in oil â€“ and this striking portrait of a beloved Northern Territory identity. 

This was one of La Gercheâ€™s two works in the 1979 Archibald â€“ the second a portrait of YolÅ‹u elder Wesley Lanhupuy. He was also a finalist in the 1979 Wynne Prize for landscape painting and Sulman Prize for genre painting.
oil on canvas

For over 30 years, Sam Fullbrook was a regular in the Archibald Prize, and won the Wynne Prize for landscape painting in 1963 and 1964. Following military service in Palestine and New Guinea during World War II, Fullbrook trained alongside Fred Williams and John Brack at Melbourneâ€™s National Gallery School under William Dargie. He then spent the 1950s and 1960s travelling and painting across Australia, working as a miner, cane cutter and stockman. Keenly interested in horses, Fullbrook was living in Brisbane in the 1970s when he became a racehorse owner and met veteran jockey Norman Stephens (1931â€“2019).

Stephens, then 43 years old, had a successful career riding before turning his hand to training. His bantam weight and legendary status earned him the nickname â€˜Whopperâ€™. Of his selection, Fullbrook said: â€˜Why on earth shouldnâ€™t we have footballers and tram conductors, and so on, as worthy subjects?â€™ It was a popular winner.

Fullbrookâ€™s portrait is painted in his deceptively naÃ¯ve style with strong blocks of colour and his spontaneous alla prima (â€˜wet on wetâ€™) technique. Critic Nancy Borlase noted: 

â€˜Fullbrook â€¦ vividly catches the character of this pert, flyweight figure with his scarlet cap and sash and lightly held whip â€¦ painted with a touch as light and as swift as a jockey in motion.â€™
synthetic polymer paintand ochres on canvas\n\nCollection: National Gallery of Australia, Canberra Purchased 2000

With this portrait of fellow Dunghutti/Ngaku man Malcolm â€˜Macâ€™ Silva (1947â€“89) â€“ lead singer of the bands Silva Linings and Black Lace â€“ Robert Campbell Junior became the first Aboriginal artist known to have exhibited in the Archibald. Campbell and Silva were both born in Kempsey, growing up on Burnt Bridge Mission, where speaking Aboriginal languages was forbidden, and children were still forcibly removed from their families.

Taught by his father, Campbell made souvenirs from found materials, incorporating his knowledge of the plants, animals and environment on Dunghutti/Ngaku Country. He eventually turned to canvas and painted narrative works, recording stories remembered from his childhood. Campbellâ€™s cartoon-style approach, using bold colours, often belies his weighty subjects: racial discrimination and the historical trauma of colonialism.

Both Campbell and Silva were living in Sydney in the 1980s. Campbell was undertaking a printmaking residency at Tin Sheds Gallery, and Silvaâ€™s rendition of â€˜Malabar mansionâ€™ â€“ written by an inmate while in Long Bay jail â€“ was the most requested song on Radio Redfern. Campbell portrays the 42-year-old Silva at his drums, mid song, titles from rockâ€™nâ€™roll and country hits drifting behind him. Tragically, Silva passed away before the portraitâ€™s selection in the Archibald; Campbell died just three years later.
oil on masonite\n\nArt Gallery of Ballarat, gift of Andrew and Jill Oliver through the Art Gallery of Ballarat Foundation, 2017

Louise Hearman is known for her dark, evocative and enigmatic paintings. Her portrait of performer Barry Humphries (1934â€“2023), who was the subject of seven Archibald finalists, was the artistâ€™s first foray inthe prize. When she learned of her win, she declared: 

â€˜â€¦ the best thing about the Archibald Prize, really, is that it gets all artists in the public eye. Today is the one day each year artists eclipse sportsmen in the news!â€™

Meeting through mutual acquaintances, Hearman found Humphries a complex person to paint, declaring â€˜heâ€™s all things at onceâ€™. With the work developing in its own way over a period of three years, she sought to capture her sitterâ€™s â€˜truly fugitive faceâ€™. Hearman evokes an unexpected and vulnerable side to the man behind his outrageous and irreverent creations. With an air of melancholy and quietude, the portrait similarly portrays the impermanence and unrelenting nature of celebrity yet captures the resilient spirit of its then 82-year-old sitter. 

In 2016 â€“ for the first time â€“ the Archibald Prize, Wynne Prize for landscape painting and Sulman Prize for genre painting were all awarded to women.
oil on canvas\n\nRockhampton Museum of Art, purchased through the Art Acquisition Fund, with assistance from the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council, 1977

In this engaging portrait, Arthur Murch has captured the larger-than-life persona of his subject, George Stevenson Wallace (1895â€“1960). From his early beginnings in vaudeville, Wallace went on to become Australiaâ€™s first genuine box-office star of â€˜the talkiesâ€™ (sound film). A versatile entertainer, Wallace performed on stage, in film and pantomime, composed songs, taught himself to play the piano, saxophone and guitar, and had his own radio show.

The artist and sitter met through a neighbour while Wallace was living with family on Sydneyâ€™s northern beaches, where Murch began preparatory sketches. Apparently, Wallace had argued with his relatives and subsequently moved to a flat in Darlinghurst. Murch was obliged to travel from his home in Avalon to Darlinghurst each day, with Wallace too anxious to leave his own home because of ill health. Ria Murch noted Wallaceâ€™s larrikin presence in the portrait, but her husbandâ€™s interest in classical nuances and the rich and shimmering tones are a clever metaphor. She said, â€˜Put a red biretta on him and Murchâ€™s Wallace could pass for a Renaissance cardinalâ€™.

Murch was committed to portraying the unique character of the people he encountered, from academics and religious figures to artists he met throughout his career. He won the 1949 Archibald with a portrait of fellow artist Bonar Dunlop.
oil on canvas on board\n\nCollection of Mr and Mrs Ronald Ooi, Singapore

Nicholas Harding portrays Australiaâ€™s foremost Shakespearean actor and director, John Bell (born 1940), whose inimitable stage presence is captured in this vital portrait of the actor in action. 

Harding was an enthusiastic follower of the Bell Shakespeare Company and had seen every production since the companyâ€™s foundation in 1990. It was, however, Barrie Koskyâ€™s 1998 production of King Lear, starring Bell, that profoundly impacted the artist. Harding noted, â€˜I sat in the front row â€¦ It was very dramatic and exciting, and Johnâ€™s performance was riveting.â€™ Harding used stage lighting to highlight Bellâ€™s figure and create sharp contrasts in his appearance, stating: 

â€˜To have him in character â€¦ allowed me to capture a more intense expression on his face. The wonderful red coat he wore as Lear has also worked well for the portrait.â€™

This was the second time Harding selected Bell as his subject, with the first in 2000. 

Over 26 years, Harding twice portrayed artist Margaret Olley (1998, 1999); Margaret Whitlam (2003, 2009), social campaigner and wife of former prime minister Gough Whitlam; and Gija artist Rusty Peters (2002, 2004). His depiction of artist Robert Dickerson was awarded the 2005 Peopleâ€™s Choice.
watercolour, gouache, synthetic polymer paint and pen on polyester canvas\n\nCollection of Cate Blanchett, England

Motherhood is a prominent theme in Del Kathryn Bartonâ€™s highly individual work, and she is acutely aware of the oftentimes competing and demanding dual roles of being an artist and mother. Cate Blanchett (born 1969) is one of the most internationally renowned and successful Australian women working in the arts today. Recognised for her multi-award-winning film, television and stage work, at the time this portrait was painted Blanchett was co-artistic director of Sydney Theatre Company, a role she held for six years. 

Blanchett preferred to be depicted with her children, and Barton wanted to create a personalised and symbolic motif particular to Blanchett, recalling:

After grilling Cate, I included a hydrangea (one of her favourite â€˜nannaâ€™ flowers), a few starlings (after an epiphany she had in the presence of a murmuration of starlings), an extraordinary Alexander McQueen gown and, of course, Dash, Roman and Iggy. The waratahs I included to symbolise a sense of place and origin and because I have always thought that they looked like crazy little UFOs hovering in the bush, pertaining to Cateâ€™s ethereal and otherworldly beauty.

In 2013, Barton became one of two women to have won the Archibald twice, joining Judy Cassab, who won in 1960 and 1966. Barton won in 2013 with a portrait of actor Hugo Weaving, and in 2008 with a self-portrait including her children.

labels.title: Barry Humphries in the character of Mrs Everage
labels.subtitle: John Brack

text.content:
oil on canvas

Art Gallery of New South Wales, purchased with funds provided by the Contemporary Art Purchase Grant from the Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council, 1975

Â© Helen Brack

John Brackâ€™s stark paintings of everyday urban life are iconic reflections on 1950s Australian middle-class existence. As the subject of this Archibald portrait, acclaimed comedian and performer Barry Humphries (1934â€“2023), recalled: 

â€˜He was different, and no one knew what to say about his work. Many critics of the time saw it as caricature, but he made a deep impression on me because his shrewd pictorial observations had an affinity with my own theatrical portrayals of Melbourne life.â€™

Brack and Humphries became friends in the late 1950s. Through their own artforms, both artists presented satirical insights into Menzies Governmentâ€“era conservatism and suburban aspirations. Humphries approached Brack about the portrait in 1968, when his fictitious character, Mrs Edna Everage, had evolved from the shy â€˜averageâ€™ housewife to the flamboyant and garrulous media personality recognised today, but before she took the title â€˜Dameâ€™. Ednaâ€™s choice of attire â€“ a uranium-green dress with contrasting hot-pink Thai silk coat â€“ was favoured by fashion-conscious housewives of the time. The Australian commented that the subject â€˜shrieks with cerise and greenâ€™.

Brackâ€™s portrayal of Humphriesâ€™ most famous persona is painted in his distinctive deadpan manner, with precise arrangements of smooth flat colour. It was the first of seven portraits of Humphries â€“ in all his guises â€“ seen in the Archibald.
oil on canvas\n\nNational Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne Felton Bequest, 1928

Russian-born actor Maurice Moscovitch (1871â€“1940) emigrated to America around 1897, where he performed for many years in the New York Yiddish theatre and on Broadway. He toured Australia in 1924 and 1925 â€“ when he sat for this portrait by John Longstaff â€“ and performed in Shakespeareâ€™s The merchant of Venice and Leo Ditrichsteinâ€™s The great lover in theatres across the country. Moscovitch later appeared in several films, including Susannah of the Mounties (1939) alongside Shirley Temple, and Charlie Chaplinâ€™s 1940 masterpiece The great dictator.

Longstaff was a well-known and in-demand portrait artist by 1925. He had studied in Paris and exhibited work at the Salon and Londonâ€™s Royal Academy in the early 1890s. Described as â€˜tall, handsome and charmingâ€™, Longstaff moved easily within the upper echelons of Melbourne society, where his talent as a portraitist secured many commissions. His skills were also recognised and celebrated in the Archibald Prize, which he won five times in all. Although this portrait reflects Longstaffâ€™s more academically inclined portrait style, one critic noted:

â€˜the winning painting is a particularly virile and expressive presentation of Mr Moscovitch and is being â€œgreatly admiredâ€ by visitors to the Art Galleryâ€™.
watercolour on canvas with paraloid varnish\n\nCherry Hood

The subject of Cherry Hoodâ€™s monumental canvas is David Helfgott (born 1947), whose extraordinary life was immortalised in the 1996 Academy Awardâ€“winning film Shine. A renowned concert pianist, Helfgott has struggled with schizoaffective disorder for much of his adult life. At age 19, he studied at Londonâ€™s Royal College of Music, but returned to Australia when his health deteriorated. In the 1980s, as Helfgott remembered, â€˜The fog lifted, I could hear again â€¦ I survivedâ€™. He returned to the concert stage and in 2021 was awarded an Order of Australia Medal.

Hoodâ€™s portrayal, while suggesting her subjectâ€™s fragile mental state, is also a celebration of the triumph of the human spirit. Hood recalled: â€˜His extraordinary music merges with his powerful magical persona to give his audience a most moving and lingering giftâ€™.

Hood has used watercolour on canvas, and the gentle trickle of the watery medium down her subjectâ€™s features creates an ethereal effect, like flowing translucent tears. She was inspired by Helfgottâ€™s resilience, affirming, â€˜So much of his emotion is represented in his wonderful face. Even so, I know that this painting can only express a moment and a fragment of itâ€™.

Seven years earlier, Hood had become the sixth woman to win the Archibald, taking out the 2002 prize with a portrait of another pianist, Simon Tedeschi.
synthetic polymer paint on canvas\n\nPrivate collection, Sydney

Fiona Lowry â€“ a graduate of Sydney College of the Arts â€“ became the eighth woman to win the Archibald Prize with this portrait of Penelope Seidler (nee Evatt, born 1938).

The niece of politician and judge Herbert â€˜Bertâ€™ Vere Evatt, whose portrait also appears in Archie 100, Seidler is an architect, accountant and patron of the arts. With her husband and professional partner Harry Seidler (1923â€“2006), she conceived the iconic Harry & Penelope Seidler House, in the Sydney suburb of Killara, whose design is finely attuned to the Australian climate and focused on a connection to the outdoors. It is within the bush landscape adjacent to the house that Lowry positions Seidler, in this portrait painted eight years after her husbandâ€™s death.

Imbued with a wistful and dream-like quality, Seidlerâ€™s otherworldly figure stares out of the canvas from her leafy surrounds. Her gaze, however, suggests inward reflection. Memory, place and history are evoked through the soft pastel tones applied with Lowryâ€™s distinctive airbrush technique. Seidler maintains a quiet, sombre demeanour that, while seemingly fragile, draws strength from, as Lowry explained, â€˜history and memories of life very well livedâ€™.

Seidler joins three other prominent architects whose portraits took out the Archibald Prize: Harold Desbrowe Annear (1921, displayed in Archie 100), Sir John Sulman (1931) and Neville Gruzman (1970).
water-based paint on board (double sided)\n\nPictures Collection, State Library Victoria. Purchased with the assistance of the State Library Victoria Foundation, 2007

This enigmatic portrait depicts Daniel Mannix (1864â€“1963), the Catholic Archbishop of Melbourne from 1917 to 1963 and one of Australiaâ€™s most famous ecclesiastics, who controversially mixed the volatile ingredients of religion and politics.

A gifted orator, the Irish-born clergyman arrived in Melbourne in 1913 and became one of the most influential public figures in 20th-century Australia. Mannix was staunchly anti-conscription, pro-Irish-republicanism and supported trade unionism, bringing him into direct conflict with Australiaâ€™s Protestant majority. He was an Archibald subject on six occasions, including portrayals by John Longstaff (1935), Clifton Pugh (1962), and this work by little-known artist James Patrick â€˜Maxâ€™ Martin, painted a decade before Mannixâ€™s death, aged 99.

Martin studied briefly in Melbourne before travelling to England in 1913 where he achieved remarkable success at Londonâ€™s Royal Academy and the Paris Salon in the 1920s, then disappeared from the spotlight, becoming a music hall entertainer and scenery painter. Martin returned to Australia in 1948. 

It is little wonder that Martin, with his Galway heritage, chose to portray Mannix. In his distinctive highly ordered style, with cool clear tones and the figure carefully contained in outline, using the form of a Gothic window, Martin positions Mannix at the heart of his city and his community. Appositely, the reverse of this two-sided work depicts the flagellation of Christ at the hands of the Romans.

oil on canvas

Gift of the Street family and the Jessie Street National Women's Library 2010

Â© Estate of Reginald Jerrold-Nathan

Jessie Lillingston (1889â€“1970) was born in India, arriving in Australia as a child. While studying arts at the University of Sydney, she met barrister Kenneth Street, who subsequently served as chief justice of New South Wales. In 1929 Jessie Street was already an activist for women as president of the Feminist Club. She became Australiaâ€™s leading feminist â€“ a crusader for family planning, equal pay and employment for women â€“ and deeply committed to social justice and peace. Street was the only female adviser in the Australian delegation to the founding conference of the United Nations in 1945 and established the UN Commission on the Status of Women and the Charter of Womenâ€™s Rights.

Following studies at Londonâ€™s Royal Academy under John Singer Sargent and Sir William Orpen, Reginald Jerrold-Nathan was an established portrait painter when he arrived in Sydney in 1924. Having painted members of the royal families of England, Denmark and Iraq, he was well-received in Sydney society. One of the prizeâ€™s most prolific artists, Jerrold-Nathan portrayed many of Australiaâ€™s leading women, including authors Dorothea Mackellar (1930) and Ethel Turner (Mrs Curlewis 1933), and feminist Linda Littlejohn (another of his four 1929 Archibald entries).

Jerrold-Nathanâ€™s penchant for painting finery can be seen in Streetâ€™s stylish velvet brocade jacket and gleaming green-beaded necklace. His subject, however, preferred more practical attire: tailor-made suits and comfortable shoes.

audio.title: Jessie Street
audio.transcript: I donâ€™t think weâ€™ve got any high-ranking women in any trade union, which is a shocking thing. After all, the trade union movement is supposed to represent both the men and the women in jobs. There must be amongst their membership, the same number of intelligent women as there are intelligent men. And I would very much hope to see in the future â€“ I donâ€™t suppose itâ€™ll come in my lifetime â€“ that they have the proper distribution of places of influence between men and women both in the governing bodies of unions, and also, later on, when things gets more socialistic, in the governing body of the industries themselves.\n\nNow I say, â€˜get more socialisticâ€™, there because many years ago I became a socialist. I read quite a lot of books about politics and so on and so forth, and it seemed to me to be the system under which the individual, whether a man or a woman, had the greatest opportunity of developing their usefulness and status. You only have to look back in history in the days of serfdom and all the rest of it. Itâ€™s as theyâ€™ve gradually overcome the limitations that were placed on them by the social system, that not only women have advanced but society itself has advanced. And of course, if you come to think of it, men and women are both components of society and if you have a horse with a lame foot or a shackled foot itâ€™s not going to gallop was well as one that hasnâ€™t got, who hasnâ€™t got any shackles on. And itâ€™s the same with the human race â€“ if youâ€™re going to shackle the women, as they have been in the past and to a certain extent still are, youâ€™re going to hold up the progress of the whole of our society.
audio.acknowledgements: This oral history of Jessie Street is from the De Berg Collection in the National Library of Australia. For more information, or to hear full versions of the recordings, visit the National Library of Australia website.

labels.title: The Hon Edward Gough Whitlam AC QC
labels.subtitle: Clifton Pugh AO

text.content: oil on hardboard\n\nHistoric Memorials Collection, Courtesy of Parliament House Art Collection, Department of Parliamentary Services, Canberra, A.C.T.

Painted in the lead-up to the 1972 Australian federal election, this was Clifton Pughâ€™s third win in the Archibald. He took the 1971 prize with a portrait of former prime minister Sir John McEwen and the 1965 prize with that of newspaperman RA Henderson. By the time of the 1972 Archibald announcement in January 1973, Labor leader Gough Whitlam (1916â€“2014) was Australiaâ€™s 21st prime minister. The win drew enormous crowds to the recently refurbished Art Gallery of New South Wales and the painting was Whitlamâ€™s choice for his official portrait at Parliament House. Whitlam wrote to the artist: â€˜My place in the history of art and yours in the history of politics are now secureâ€™.

Whitlam â€“ like his portrait â€“ was either revered or derided, according to political predilection. He introduced many controversial policy measures and social reforms that radically changed Australiaâ€™s economic, legal and cultural landscape: establishing the Australia Council for the Arts, eliminating university fees, abolishing the death penalty, and ending military conscription. His troubled administration, however, was cut short when he was dismissed by the governor-general in 1975. 

Trained at Melbourneâ€™s National Gallery School, Pugh was best known for his bush landscapes, but became a sought-after portraitist. He made multiple versions of Whitlamâ€™s portrait, trying to capture the dynamic Labor leader and cement his place in Archibald legend.
